Sensor Networks with Random Links: Topology Design for Distributed Consensus

Soummya Kar and JosÃ© M.Â F.Â Mouraâˆ— The authors are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA 15213 (e-mail: soummyak@andrew.cmu.edu, moura@ece.cmu.edu, ph: (412)268-6341, fax: (412)268-3890.)Work supported by the DARPA DSO Advanced Computing and Mathematics Program Integrated Sensing and Processing (ISP) Initiative under ARO grant #Â DAAD19-02-1-0180, by NSF under grants #Â ECS-0225449 andÂ #Â CNS-0428404, and by an IBM Faculty Award.
Abstract

In a sensor network, in practice, the communication among sensors is subject to: (1) errors or failures at random times; (2) costs; and (3) constraints since sensors and networks operate under scarce resources, such as power, data rate, or communication. The signal-to-noise ratioÂ (SNR) is usually a main factor in determining the probability of error (or of communication failure) in a link. These probabilities are then a proxy for the SNR under which the links operate. The paper studies the problem of designing the topology, i.e., assigning the probabilities of reliable communication among sensors (or of link failures) to maximize the rate of convergence of average consensus, when the link communication costs are taken into account, and there is an overall communication budget constraint. To consider this problem, we address a number of preliminary issues: (1) model the network as a random topology; (2) establish necessary and sufficient conditions for mean square sense (mss) and almost sure (a.s.) convergence of average consensus when network links fail; and, in particular, (3) show that a necessary and sufficient condition for both mss and a.s.Â convergence is for the algebraic connectivity of the mean graph describing the network topology to be strictly positive. With these results, we formulate topology design, subject to random link failures and to a communication cost constraint, as a constrained convex optimization problem to which we apply semidefinite programming techniques. We show by an extensive numerical study that the optimal design improves significantly the convergence speed of the consensus algorithm and can achieve the asymptotic performance of a non-random network at a fraction of the communication cost.

Key words: Sensor networks, topology, consensus, distributed decision, convergence, graph, Laplacian, spectral graph theory.

I Introduction

We consider the design of the optimal topology, i.e., the communication configuration of a sensor network that maximizes the convergence rate of average consensus. Average consensus is a distributed algorithm that has been considered by Tsitsiklis in his PhD thesis, [1], see alsoÂ [2], found application recently in several areas, and is the subject of active research, e.g,, [3, 4, 5, 6].

This topology design for sensor networks has not received much attention in the literature. ReferencesÂ [7] andÂ [8] consider restrict it to classes of random graphs, in particular, small-world topologies. The more general question of designing the topology that maximizes the convergence rate, under a constraint on the number of network links, was considered in our previous work, [9, 10, 11], where we reduced to average consensus the problem of distributed inference in sensor networks; see alsoÂ [12].

Realistic networks operate under stress: (1) noise and errors cause links to fail at random times; (2) communication among sensors entails a cost; and (3) scarcity of resources constrain sensors and networks operation. We model such a non-deterministic network topology as a random field. Specifically, we assume the following: 1) at each iteration of the consensus algorithm, a network link is active with some probability, referred to as link formation or utilization probability; 2) network links have different link formation probabilities; 3) links fail or are alive independently of each other; and 4) the link formation probabilities remain constant across iterations. Designing the network topology corresponds then to (1) fixing the probability, or fraction of time, each link is used, (2) knowing that communication among sensors may be cheap (e.g., sensors are geographically close), or expensive, and (3) recognizing that there is an overall budget constraint taxing the communication in the network.

The paper extends our preliminary convergence results, [13], on networks with random links. The recent paperÂ [14] adopts a similar model and analyzes convergence properties using ergodicity of stochastic matrices. Consensus with a randomized network also relates to gossip algorithms, [15], where only a single pair of randomly selected sensors is allowed to communicate at each iteration, and the communication exchanged by the nodes is averaged. In our randomized consensus, we use multiple randomly selected links at each iteration and, in contradistinction withÂ [15], we design the optimal topology, i.e., the optimal weight (not simple average) and the optimal probabilities of edge utilization, recognizing that communication entails costs, and that there is a communication cost constraint. Other recent work on evolving topologies includesÂ [16] that considers continuous time consensus in networks with switching topologies and communication delays, andÂ [17] that studies distributed consensus when the network is a complete graph with identical link failure probabilities on all links.

We outline the paper. SectionÂ II summarizes spectral graph theory concepts like the graph LaplacianÂ Lğ¿L and the graph algebraic connectivity Î»2â€‹(L)subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\lambda_{2}(L). The Section formulates the problem of distributed average consensus with random link failures. SectionsÂ III and IV derive necessary and sufficient conditions for convergence of the mean state, mss convergence, and a.s.Â convergence in terms of the average Eâ€‹{Î»2â€‹(L)}Esubscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left\{\lambda_{2}\left(L\right)\right\} and in terms of Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right), where LÂ¯=Eâ€‹(L)Â¯ğ¿Eğ¿\overline{L}=\mbox{E}\left(L\right). SectionÂ V presents bounds on the mss convergence rate. SectionÂ VI addresses the topology design for random networks with communication cost constraints. We formulate a first version of the problem, the randomized distributed consensus with a communication cost constraint (RCCC), and then an alternate version, which we show is a convex constrained optimization problem, to which we apply semidefinite programmingÂ (SDP) techniques. SectionÂ VII studies the performance of the topologies found by solving numerically the SDP optimization. We show that these designs can improve significantly the convergence rate, for example, by a factor ofÂ 333, when compared to geometric networks (networks where sensors communicate with every other sensor within a fixed radius) and that they can achieve practically the (asymptotic) performance of a nonrandom network at a fraction, e.g., 50Â %, of the communication cost per iteration. SectionÂ VIII concludes the paper.

II Distributed Average Consensus

SubsectionÂ II-A presents two network models: Model 1) Nonrandomtopology in paragraphÂ II-A1; and Model 2) Randomtopology in paragraphÂ II-A2. Â SubsectionÂ II-B considers distributed average consensus with nonrandom topologies in ParagraphÂ II-B1 and random topologies in ParagraphÂ II-B2. We assume synchronous communication throughout.

II-A Nonrandom and Random Topologies

In a nonrandom topology, the communication channels stay available whenever the sensors need to communicate. This model is described in paragraphÂ II-A1, where we recall basic concepts from graph theory. In many sensor network applications, it makes sense to consider that links among sensors may fail or become alive at random times. This models, for example, applications when the network uses an ARQ protocol and no acknowledgement packet is received within the protocol time window, in which case the transmitted packet is assumed to be dropped or lost. This is also the case, when the transmission is detected in error. The random topology introduced in paragraphÂ II-A2 models these networks.

II-A1 Nonrandom topology

The nonrandom topology is defined by an undirected graph G=(V,â„°)ğºğ‘‰â„°G=(V,\mathcal{E}), where Vğ‘‰V is the set of vertices that model the sensors and â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is the set of edges that model the communication channels. We refer toÂ GğºG as the supergraph, â„°â„°\mathcal{E} as the superset of edges, and edges in â„°â„°\mathcal{E} as realizable edges or links. This terminology becomes better motivated when we consider the random topology in SubsectionÂ II-A2. The cardinalities of the sets |V|=Nğ‘‰ğ‘|V|=N and |â„°|=Mâ„°ğ‘€|\mathcal{E}|=M give the number of network sensors and the number of channels or links, respectively. II-A2 Random Topology

We consider sensor networks where failures may occur at random due to noise as when packets are dropped. If a link fails at timeÂ iğ‘–i, it can come back online at a later time (a failed transmission may be succeeded by a successful one.) We describe a graph model for this random topology. We start with the model in paragraphÂ II-A1 of a simple, connected supergraph G=(V,â„°)ğºğ‘‰â„°G=\left(V,\mathcal{E}\right) with |V|=Nğ‘‰ğ‘|V|=N and |â„°|=Mâ„°ğ‘€|\mathcal{E}|=M. The superset of edges â„°â„°\mathcal{E} collects the realizable edges, i.e., the channels that are established directly among sensors in the network when all realizable links are online. These channels may fail at random times, but if (n,l)âˆ‰â„°ğ‘›ğ‘™â„°(n,l)\notin\mathcal{E} then sensorsÂ nğ‘›n andÂ lğ‘™l do not communicate directlyâ€”of course, they still communicate by rerouting their messages through one of the paths connecting them inÂ GğºG, sinceÂ GğºG is connected. We now construct the model for the random topology problem, see also [13, 14, 15].

We assume that for any realizable edges (n,l)â‰ (m,k)ğ‘›ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘˜(n,l)\neq(m,k) the corresponding Bernoulli processes are statistically independent. II-B Average Consensus

We overview average consensus, see [1, 2] and also for recent work [3]. II-B2 Average consensus: Random topology

At each timeÂ iğ‘–i, the graph Gâ€‹(i)=(V,Eâ€‹(i))ğºğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘–G(i)=\left(V,E(i)\right) is random. Likewise, the weight matrices Wâ€‹(i)ğ‘Šğ‘–W(i), i=0,1,â€¦ğ‘–01â€¦i=0,1,... are also iid random matrices. We often drop the time indexÂ iğ‘–i in the random matricesÂ Lâ€‹(i)ğ¿ğ‘–L(i) andÂ Wâ€‹(i)ğ‘Šğ‘–W(i) or their statistics. IteratingÂ (12) with this time dependent weight matrix leads to

III Preliminary Results

For a given probability distribution (and hence Pğ‘ƒP) of Lğ¿L, Eâ€‹[Ïâ€‹(Wâˆ’1Nâ€‹J)]Edelimited-[]ğœŒğ‘Š1ğ‘ğ½\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] is convex onÂ Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

Lemma 11

For a given choice of Î±ğ›¼\alpha,

Eâ€‹[Ïâ€‹(Wâˆ’1Nâ€‹J)]â‰¥Ïâ€‹(WÂ¯âˆ’1Nâ€‹J)Edelimited-[]ğœŒğ‘Š1ğ‘ğ½ğœŒÂ¯ğ‘Š1ğ‘ğ½\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]\geq\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) (47)

IV Convergence of Average Consensus: Random Topology

For average consensus in random topologies, we start by considering the convergence of the state

âˆ€ğ±â€‹(0)âˆˆâ„NÃ—1:limiâ†’âˆğ±â€‹(i)=ğ±avg:for-allğ±0superscriptâ„ğ‘1subscriptâ†’ğ‘–ğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±avg\forall\mathbf{x}(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1}:\>\>\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\mathbf{x}(i)=\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}} (48)

IV-A2 Fastest mean convergence topology

Corollary 20

mss convergence cannot be faster than convergence of the mean vector.

The Corollary follows from the Theorem and LemmaÂ 11.

Let Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)>0subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. By LemmaÂ 3, LÂ¯Â¯ğ¿\overline{L} is irreducible. Let dmaxâ€‹(G)subscriptğ‘‘maxğºd_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}}(G) be the maximum vertex degree of graph GğºG. Then, from spectral graph theory, seeÂ [23],

TheoremÂ 21 gives necessary and sufficient conditions on the probability distribution of the Laplacian Lğ¿L for mean square convergence. This is significant as it relates mss convergence to the network topology. A note on TheoremsÂ 21 andÂ 23: We consider only equal weights, i.e., all the link weights are assigned the same weight Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Thus, the necessary condition established in TheoremsÂ 21 andÂ 23 for mssÂ convergence and a.s.Â convergence respectively in the constant link weight case holds for the more general weight assignments also. In other words, if we have a weight assignment (with possibly different weights for different links) for which the consensus algorithm converges in mss (and a.s.), then we can always find a constant weight Î±ğ›¼\alpha for which the consensus algorithm converges in mss (and a.s.)

However, given a particular distribution of the Laplacian Lğ¿L, the actual choice of Î±ğ›¼\alpha plays a significant role in determining the convergence rate. Thus, given a particular distribution of Lğ¿L, we must choose that value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha that maximizes the convergence speed. From TheoremÂ 18, we note that, the smaller the mss-convergence factor Câ€‹(Î±,LÂ¯)ğ¶ğ›¼Â¯ğ¿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) given byÂ (64) is, the faster the convergence is. VI Consensus With Communication Constraints: Topology Optimization

In the previous sections, we analyzed the impact of the probability distribution Dğ·D of the network topology on the mss convergence rate of the distributed average consensus algorithm. This section studies the problem of sensor network topology optimization for fast consensus in the presence of inter-sensor communication (or infrastructure) cost constraints. We assume equal link weights throughout.

We consider Nğ‘N sensors and a symmetric cost matrix Cğ¶C, where the entry Cnâ€‹lsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘™C_{nl} is the cost (communication or infrastructure) incurred per iteration when sensors nğ‘›n and lğ‘™l communicate. The goal is to design the connectivity graph that leads to the fastest convergence rate under a constraint on the total communication cost per iteration. Depending on the structure of the cost matrix Cğ¶C and the network topology (deterministic or randomized), this optimization problem may have the following variants:

  1. 1.

    Fixed topology with equal costs: Here the entries Cnâ€‹lsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘™C_{nl} of the cost matrix Cğ¶C are all equal and we look for the optimal fixed or deterministic topology leading to fastest convergence of the consensus algorithm. It is easy to see that the equal cost assumption translates into a constraint on the number of network links and the optimal solution is essentially the class of non-bipartite Ramanujan graphs (seeÂ [9, 10, 11].)

  2. 2.

    Fixed topology with different costs (FCCC): In this case the inter-sensor costs Cnâ€‹lsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘™C_{nl} may be different, and we seek the optimal fixed or deterministic topology leading to fastest convergence. This is a difficult combinatorial optimization problem and there is no closed form solution in general.

  3. 3.

    Random topology with different costs (RCCC): This is the most general problem, where the costs Cnâ€‹lsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘™C_{nl} may be different and we look for the optimal (random or deterministic) topology leading to the fastest convergence rate under a communication cost constraint. Because the network is random, it makes sense to constrain the (network) average (expected) communication cost per iteration. Likewise, convergence should also be interpreted in a probabilistic sense, for example, the mean square convergence. To summarize, in the RCCC problem, we are concerned with: (i) designing the optimal probability of edge formation matrix Pğ‘ƒP, (ii) under an average communication cost constraint, (iii) leading to the fastest mss convergence rate. RCCC reduces to FCCC, if the entries of the optimal Pğ‘ƒP are 0 or 1. In this sense, the RCCC problem relaxes the difficult combinatorial FCCC problem and, as we will see later, will usually lead to better overall solutions, especially under medium to low communication cost constraints. This is because with a fixed topology, we are forced to use the same network always, while in the random topology case we can occasionally make use of very good networks, still satisfying the cost constraint. We can draw an analogy between RCCC and gossip algorithms (seeÂ [15].) However the context and assumptions of the two problems are different. ReferenceÂ [15] optimizes the gossip probabilities for a given network topology under the gossip protocolâ€”only two nodes, randomly selected with gossip probability, can communicate at each iterationâ€” andÂ [15] does not impose a communication cost constraint. In contrast, we design the optimal (equal) weightÂ Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the optimalÂ Pğ‘ƒP matrix leading to the fastest mss convergence rate, under an average cost constraint. The topology solution that we determine gives the percentage of time a link is to be used, or, as another interpretation, the probability of error asssociated with reliable communication in a given link. Because signal-to-noise ratioÂ (SNR) determines often the probability of error, enforcing the topology, i.e., Pğ‘ƒP, is like selecting the SNR for each link.

VI-A Random Topology with Communication Cost Constraints (RCCC)

We are given Nğ‘N sensors. We model the cost of communication by an NÃ—Nğ‘ğ‘N\times N matrixÂ C=CTğ¶superscriptğ¶ğ‘‡C=C^{T}. The entry Cnâ€‹lâ‰¥0subscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘™0C_{nl}\geq 0, nâ‰ lğ‘›ğ‘™n\neq l, is the cost incurred by a single communication between nodes nğ‘›n and lğ‘™l. Entry Cnâ€‹l=+âˆsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘™C_{nl}=+\infty precludes sensorsÂ nğ‘›n andÂ lğ‘™l from communicating. Let Pğ‘ƒP be the probability of edge formation matrix. The diagonal entries of Pğ‘ƒP are zero, although each node can access its data with zero cost. The Pğ‘ƒP matrix induces a probability distribution on the Laplacian Lâ€‹(i)ğ¿ğ‘–L(i), which at timeÂ iğ‘–i is a random instantiation based on theÂ Pğ‘ƒP matrix. The total cost incurred at stage iğ‘–i is

VI-B Alternate Randomized Consensus under Communication Cost Constraints (ARCCC)

The RCCC problem inÂ (92) is very difficult to solve. We formulate an alternate randomized consensus under communication cost constraintsÂ (ARCCC) problem. We show successively: (i) ARCCC is convex and can be solved by fast numerical optimization procedures; (ii) ARCCC is a good approximation toÂ (92); and (iii) ARCCC leads to topologies with good convergence rates. PointÂ (i) is in this section, while pointsÂ (ii) andÂ (iii) are studied in SectionÂ VII-C where we analyze the performance of ARCCC.

ARCCC: Problem Formulation.

Lemma 26

The optimization problemÂ ARCCC inÂ (93) is convex.

Proof.

From LemmaÂ 4, it follows that the objective Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) is a concave function of LÂ¯Â¯ğ¿\overline{L}. Also, the set of LÂ¯Â¯ğ¿\overline{L} satisfying the constraints forms a convex set. Hence, ARCCC maximizes a concave function over a convex set; so, it is convex. âˆ

The optimization problem in LemmaÂ 26 is a semidefinite programming (SDP) problem that can be solved numerically in efficient ways, see referencesÂ [29, 30] for SDP solving methods (see alsoÂ [31, 32] for constrained optimization of graph Laplacian eigenvalues.)

VII Topology Optimization: Performance Results

In this section, SubsectionÂ VII-A discusses in what sense the ARCCC topology optimization problem introduced in SectionÂ VI-B and eqn.Â (93) is a good approximation to the original RCCC topology optimization formulation of SectionÂ VI-A and eqn.Â (92). SubsectionÂ VII-B establishes bounds on the optimal value as a function of the communication constraint. Finally, SubsectionÂ VII-C illustrates by a numerical study that the ARCCC optimization obtains topologies for which the distributed consensus exhibits fast convergence.

VII-A ARCCC as a Good Approximation to RCCC

The difficulty with RCCC stems from the fact that it involves joint optimization over bothÂ Î±ğ›¼\alpha andÂ LÂ¯Â¯ğ¿\overline{L}. For a given LÂ¯Â¯ğ¿\overline{L}, there is, in general, no closed form solution of

Sgâˆ—â€‹(LÂ¯)=maxÎ±âˆˆâ„â¡Sgâ€‹(Î±,LÂ¯)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†gâˆ—Â¯ğ¿subscriptğ›¼â„subscriptğ‘†gğ›¼Â¯ğ¿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right)=\max_{\alpha\in\mathbb{R}}S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) (94)

We first present a plausible argument of why ARCCC is a good surrogate for RCCC, and then present numerical results that justify this argument.

We present a plausible argument in two steps. First, we replace in RCCC the maximization of Sgâˆ—â€‹(LÂ¯)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†gâˆ—Â¯ğ¿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) by the maximization of Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]. We justify this step by noting that eqn.Â (88) bounds Sgâˆ—â€‹(LÂ¯)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†gâˆ—Â¯ğ¿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L}) from below and this lower bound shows that larger values of Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] lead to higher Sgâˆ—â€‹(LÂ¯)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†gâˆ—Â¯ğ¿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right). This suggests that, for a given set of distributions LÂ¯âˆˆğ’Ÿâ€‹(U)Â¯ğ¿ğ’Ÿğ‘ˆ\overline{L}\in\mathcal{D}(U), the quantity Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] may provide an ordering on the elements of ğ’Ÿâ€‹(U)ğ’Ÿğ‘ˆ\mathcal{D}(U) with respect to the mss convergence rate Sgâˆ—â€‹(LÂ¯)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†gâˆ—Â¯ğ¿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right). Hence, a topology with fast convergence rate satisfying the communication constraintÂ Uğ‘ˆU is provided by the distribution LÂ¯âˆ—âˆˆğ’Ÿâ€‹(U)superscriptÂ¯ğ¿âˆ—ğ’Ÿğ‘ˆ\overline{L}^{\ast}\in\mathcal{D}(U) that maximizes the quantity Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] over the set ğ’Ÿâ€‹(U)ğ’Ÿğ‘ˆ\mathcal{D}(U).

This is not enough to get a reasonable topology optimization problem, since computing Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] is costly, because its evaluation requires costly Monte-Carlo simulations (seeÂ [13].) The second step replaces the optimization of Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] by the maximization of Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}), which simply involves computing the second eigenvalue of P=LÂ¯ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ¿P=\overline{L}, no Monte Carlo simulations being involved. This step is justified on the basis of LemmaÂ 5, which upper-bounds Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] by Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}). This suggests that for Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] to be large, Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}) should be large.

Putting together the two steps, the RCCC problem in eqn.Â (92) is successively approximated by

For each Pğ‘ƒP, we also obtain the corresponding Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}) by eqn.Â (27). This is an extensive and computationally expensive simulation. Fig.Â 1 displays the results by plotting the convergence rate Sgâˆ—â€‹(LÂ¯)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†gâˆ—Â¯ğ¿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) with respect to Eâ€‹[Î»2â€‹(L)]Edelimited-[]subscriptğœ†2ğ¿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right], left plot, and with respect to Î»2â€‹(LÂ¯)subscriptğœ†2Â¯ğ¿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right), right plot. This study shows that optimal topologies with respect to ARCCC should be good topologies with respect to RCCC.

VIII Conclusions

The paper presents the design of the topology of a sensor network to maximize the convergence rate of the consensus algorithm as a convex optimization problem. We consider that the communication channels among sensors may fail at random times, that communication among sensors incurs a cost, and that there is an overall communication cost constraint in the network. We first establish necessary and sufficient conditions for mss convergence and a.s.Â convergence in terms of the expected value of the algebraic connectivity of the random graph defining the network topology and in terms of the algebraic connectivity of the average topology. We apply semidefinite programming to solve numerically for the optimal topology design of the random network subject to the communication cost constraint. Because the topology is random, the solution to this optimization specifies for each realizable link its probability of error (aka, SNR), or the fraction of time the link is expected to be active. We show by a simulation study that the resulting topology design can improve by about 300Â % the convergence speed of average consensus over more common designs, e.g., geometric topologies where sensors communicate with sensors within a fixed distance. Our study also shows that the optimal random topology can achieve the convergence speed of a non-random network at a fraction of the cost.
